From a nation so .‘ populous, so tractable, and of so gentle a dis- position, great accessions were reasonably ex- pected to Christianity, but Satan confounded all these fair hopes. Cangapol‘, the potentate > of that region, long beheld these Christian co-⁴ lonies with gloomy and envious eyes. Through them he thought that friendships- would be formed with the SpaniardS, the freedom of the southern nations endangered, and his own power in these parts gradually diminished, and ultimately suppressed. Hence he turned his whole heart and thoughts to hastening the de- struction of the new town, and the banishment of the Fathers who taught the strange religion.
